body: R: @dhalperi Some of the helper code for tests is duplicated from the main source. I thought of creating a common utility across them but that would require some refactoring  and also make the tests a little ugly, so decided not to. Let me know your thoughts.
Manually close PR at your leisure
Seems like Travis was a flake, still merging.

LGTM.

There is a git convention of prefixing `fixup!` to commits that are just fixes to the prior commit (comes from the [use of `--autosquash` when rebasing](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-rebase) but I will do it manually). My impression is that there is only really one commit of changes here. Can you either squash them yourself and `git push -f` or else reword the commits to start with `fixup!`?

All of this is to just so that I don't have to sort out the right commit message. You can also just reply and let me know that the first commit message is the one you care about and I can squash the rest into that, which is what this looks like.

@robertwb do you know how this test should be updated?

`snippets_test.TypeHintsTest.test_deterministic_key` is failing with

```
File "/Users/travis/build/apache/incubator-beam/sdks/python/apache_beam/transforms/ptransform.py", line 584, in process_argspec_fn
raise NotImplementedError
```

Failing at applying this:

`beam.CombinePerKey(sum).with_input_types(beam.typehints.Tuple[Player, int]))`

It works if when I locally roll back #633

I think `CombinePerKey` needs to implement `process_argspec_fn` after this change.
LGTM! If no one objects I'll merge it later today.

Thanks Kenn.

Squashed commits into a single commit. PTAL.
@aaltay, @dhalperi, the problem is that I can't reproduce why Jenkins executes the `exec:java` Maven goal...

Abandoning this PR and starting clean to not have some messed up commit history.
Just checking in - how is it going? Anything I can do to facilitate?
Thanks @silviulica. I added something similar and tests are passing. It seems like, that function is used to type check the wrapped callable.
Will pull as soon as the presubmits pass.

The ball is in my court to address the review comments. I also need to see why the unit tests fail in Jenkins when they pass locally. Progress may be slow for the next few weeks, hope to get some updates in soon.
Just one comment, but other than that looks good, and nice to have all these tests again!
Hi @robertwb, could you please take a look?
Can you set up a meeting for review? Probably faster.

@robertwb - the code analysis does not pick up that the lambda expression returns a KV[str, str]?
We will need to give a warning to people for similar cases so they do not get unexpected performance degradation.

Agreed, the type inference should be smarter (I don't think it handles slices). I think we also need to fall back to better default than pickling, e.g.

https://github.com/robertwb/incubator-beam/commit/af73fff4092913fb0050ee9ebec874535743b5eb

(sorry for the delay in review)

Exposing the `CombineFn` in `Combine.Globally` is fine by me. The fundamental semantic data that makes up a transform is very reasonable to expose, and we've done the same whenever we needed it to create an adequate override. LGTM to that.

From another perspective, that `fn` will certainly be present in the language-agnostic pipeline representation in the forthcoming "Runner API" (as per the proposal doc, where it is in the Avro schema) so it is certainly public data.

Curious. I can't say much about the details there. What was at the other end of the future that timed out when the embedded Gearpump cluster was starting up?

I'll pull and try it to see if my environment reproduces the issue.
Prior to yesterday, Jenkins wasn't cleaning up its workspace properly. I recommend trying it again, if you got the unit tests to pass locally.
Jenkins is throwing NPEs trying to execute these tests. See the tests in the link

@wikier : I believe the java goal is coming [from the root pom](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/pom.xml#L760):

``` xml
        <plugin>
          <groupId>org.codehaus.mojo</groupId>
          <artifactId>exec-maven-plugin</artifactId>
          <version>1.4.0</version>
          <executions>
            <execution>
              <phase>verify</phase>
              <goals>
                <goal>java</goal>
              </goals>
            </execution>
          </executions>
          <configuration>
            <cleanupDaemonThreads>false</cleanupDaemonThreads>
            <systemProperties>
              <systemProperty>
                <key>java.util.logging.config.file</key>
                <value>logging.properties</value>
              </systemProperty>
            </systemProperties>
          </configuration>
        </plugin>
```

LGTM Nice touch adding the autocomplete tests so we catch this in the future.
@robertwb bottom line is that this requires a bit more thought. It gets into infinite recursion while pickling functions.

R: @dhalperi 
Dan, could you review the waitToFinish() and cancel() APIs first?
After that I will add runners owners to get their approval. And, then have a detailed review on this PR.

R: @dhalperi 

This seems to work, and I can see the uber-jar version of netty-tcnative-boringssl-static 1.1.33.Fork13 is [available on maven-central](http://central.maven.org/maven2/io/netty/netty-tcnative-boringssl-static/1.1.33.Fork13/netty-tcnative-boringssl-static-1.1.33.Fork13.jar). Are there other tests I should run to validate that it works?

@dhalperi Travis failed on Checkstyle for a file that this PR did not change. https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-beam/builds/144535408

Also the checkstyle passed on my local machine. Any idea what happened?

Can you investigate? My initial guess is that the Jenkins maven command line and the travis maven command line are different, and checkstyle only runs in one of the profiles for at least some modules.

Running BigTableReadIT tests confirm that the Fork13 netty-tcnative-boringssl-static artifact in fact doesn't have an uber-jar, and doesn't work. It seems there's no getting around the os-maven-plugin dependency leak. I've added the extension to the examples-java module, which is the only other module which depends on gcp-io.

@dhalperi https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/646 added the unused import and got merged after I pull rebased my branch. @swegner fixed it in https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/649. Updated my branch with these changes, hopefully will pass now.

@dhalperi all comments fixed and all checks passed :)
This particular change seems to break Spark.

Squashed commits into a single commit and updated the commit message.

Please let me know if anything else needs to be updated.
Jenkins failure is not related to the PR: it failed on archetype when retrieving the maven-archetype-plugin from Central.

While this fix solves the problem, I'm wondering about this solution.. Is it OK to have the default sharding of the direct runner random (within range) ? to the best of my knowledge, sharding is related to the nature (and volume)  of the data, so for a word count example of 2 words, you might end-up having 7 output files...
I guess this depends on how we see the `DirectRunner`, if it's for examples and testing, it's fair enough, but if it's also an out-of-the-box in-memory runner to get started with (until your business grows, and you actually start having **Big Data**) I'm not sure that's a good fit.
WDYT ?

Should pylint run in jenkins?

Tiny nit: The coverage of `PAssertTest` over the public API of `PAssert` is not that great. I understand that since it is all one underlying method with different `PaneExtractor` that the correctness is essentially derived from the testing of `PaneExtractorsTest`, but it would be nice to have explicit tests in `PAssertTest` for some of these.
For now, I'm closing this PR.
I'm closing this PR for now.

@dhalperi We should run pylint in jenkins. It is already running in post-commit job. It will be part of pre-commit jobs once we have anything running in jenkins. It will require #537 or a new pre-commit job.
Along with this, you should remove the runtime dep on runners-core
